question.text: Two identical calorimeters <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> contain an equal quantity of water at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>20</mn><mo> </mo><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>. A <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>5</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math> piece of metal <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></math> of specific heat <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>0.2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal"> </mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mo> </mo><mo>°</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math> is dropped into <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>5</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></math> piece of metal <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> is dropped into <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>. The equilibrium temperature in <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>22</mn><mo> </mo><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> and that in <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>23</mn><mo> </mo><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>. The initial temperature of both the metals was <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>40</mn><mo> </mo><mo>°</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>. The specific heat of metal <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi></math> (in <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mo> </mo><mo>°</mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math>) is

solution.text:
For X:5×0.2×(40-22)

=m×C×22-20

For Y:5×C×(40-23)

=m×C×(23-20)

⇒C=2785
